raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "Antibodies directed against phospholipids", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "This patient presents with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the setting of SLE and a history of spontaneous abortion. Key lab findings include a prolonged PTT (90 sec) that does NOT correct with mixing study (89 sec), indicating the presence of an inhibitor rather than a factor deficiency. Normal platelet count (250,000) and normal PT (14 sec) are also noted. This clinical picture - thrombosis, pregnancy loss, prolonged PTT not correcting with mixing study, and SLE - is classic for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). APS is caused by antiphospholipid antibodies (including lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-beta-2-glycoprotein I antibodies). Option 0 (anti-GpIIb/IIIa) would cause thrombocytopenia, not thrombosis. Option 2 lacks specificity. Option 3 (vitamin K deficiency) would prolong PT more than PTT and would correct with mixing study."}
